Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: General survey knowledge about the history of robotic systems and some of today's technologies and their concepts.
I learned about robotics and the thought that goes into building them from a command standpoint.
I learned about robots and how to code robots
Understand the history and foundations for intelligent robotic systems design.
This class provided a thorough overview of what the process of determining intelligence for robots is. It was interesting and interactive. I loved the lectures.

We learned about robotics starting from very early in robotics history (Braitenberg vehicles) to very recent developments. We learned about architectures and the robots that used them, and the pros and cons for each architecture. We learned a lot about how humans interact with robots and what robots mean in terms of societal development. We covered a huge variety of topics but learned a satisfying amount about all of them.
This course was a pretty general survey of robotics. We just learned a lot about many different parts of the field.
An overview of robotics design concepts and important ideas in robotics.
I learned a lot about robot architecture and the development of the field of robotics.

I gained a broad overview of challenges and achievements in the field of robotics. In particular, we took a look at some behavior based and reactive architectures, robots in social contexts, hardware for sensing, and some (very) basic AI techniques.
I learned a ton in this course, from robotics theory to actual coding techniques in C. I particularly enjoyed the units on behavior-based architectures, as the material was 100 percent new to me.
I learned about the evolution of robots' architectures and the ingredients needed to make them  work and interact with humans.
I learned about the history of robotics as well as useful topics in building different architectures for them, including pros and cons.
History of robotics, general concepts of robotics and related to robotics
This course teaches you about robots. What kinds are out there, how they work, and in a rough sense how you could go about building them.
I learned about different topics in robotics as well as different topics in CS that are relevant to robotics (i.e. machine learning, computer vision, autonomous driving).
Gained knowledge about designing robotics architectures. Insights into the field of artificial intelligence from a robotics perspective.
I attained a basic knowledge of a number of machine architectures and machine learning/AI.

This course was a very interesting exploration of the history of robotics, the latest architectures and algorithms used in robotics as well as what it means for a robot to be intelligent. The course made me realize how many specific details and functions that we as humans take for granted need a lot of work to get right in a robot.
I gained a general understanding of how and why robots work.
Improved my c programming

I gained a high-level knowledge of the software behind intelligent robots. This course works on problem solving and design as you have to design a number of software architectures of robots in. I gained insights both into the future of intelligent robotics and also the current technologies.
I learned a lot about different robotics systems and the general evolution of intelligent robotics.
This class gave me a much better idea of what current issues in robotics are, and how different parts of computer science can be applied to robotics.

Learnt a great deal about development in robotics over the last century. Very interesting to learn about the different architecture and see how codes can be transformed into real-life robot behaviors.
Learned about different types of robot architectures, history of robotics, how to use Webots.
Learned a lot about robot architecture and different applications of robots.

I learned about many topics in robotics and intelligent robotics, beginning from definitions of intelligence to many attempts and challenges for implmenting intelligent robots. The course was taught mostly at a survey level. Scaz was awesome in his lectures and I really felt like I got a very deep understanding of the field at an intuitive level. I also had practice implementing some commonly used techniques we talked about such as genetic algorithms and Q learning.
A good, if general, introduction to robotics - heavy cognitive science, but limited computer science knowledge in addition to engineering.

I felt like the depth of this course was too shallow. I would have wanted to dive deeper into certain topics that we talked about instead of covering stories of robot success stories or giving a bunch of examples that I probably won't remember in the future. I did feel like I learned a lot more about the field than I knew prior this course.
This class was fine. I learned some interesting material and it was very relaxed.

Scaz is a great, charismatic lecturer. The class meets three times a week for relatively short times, which makes it easy to pay attention. The initial psets were frustrating because they were vague and underspecified. Psets 4 and 5 were more interesting as they required coding. 

TAs were also great and came in clutch during OH. I wish there was a Piazza though.
Not really
Thorough and engaging lectures.
The lectures were very interesting. However, the last two problem sets were a huge jump in difficulty with not enough preparation.

I thought this course was well done; lectures were very interesting. Scaz is a great lecturer and is able to keep lectures engaging by including videos and providing a social perspective to the robots. The workload wasn't bad, 5 problem sets, and I loved the design aspect of the problem sets. The design questions were very open ended but from an engineering standpoint, I loved that. You could come up with whatever answer you wanted as long as it worked. The midterm and final were fair, although with such a range of subjects it was a bit difficult to tell what would be on the final. Even so, the final was very fair.

The lectures in this class in general were pretty interesting. However the main issue was the grading as there wasnt really a right answer and it seemed like the grading was kind of arbitrary sometimes. Also they graded based on style which I think is unfair if you dont tell someone youre going to grade on style.

Very efficient lectures, very comprehensive syllabus. I liked it as something in-between a survey of robotics and studying specific concepts in-depth. Some classes felt wasteful, unimportant, didn't fit in in a way that made sense  evolving robots, dynamical systems, false assumptions, autonomous cars, but the vast majority of classes seemed interesting, engaging, and/or relevant and I appreciated the new ideas to think about, particularly in a less technical manner.

The course excels in its instruction--Scaz is a wonderful teacher who is clearly incredibly passionate about robotics. The only thing I would change about the course would be to set up a Piazza forum to ask questions.

Scaz is a great lecturer and classes are very engaging. The course does a great job at inspiring you to pursue future careers in robotics and AI, but the downside of trying to cover such an immense field in 3 months is that you won't get to dive very deep into actually programming or implementing anything non-trivial.  Lectures veer between being very insightful and informative, to some that are essentially looking at videos of cool robots. Problem sets can be challenging and uncertain (no test cases to pass), but do not need significant mathematical or programming skills, and are definitely doable. The TAs are great and really helpful, and it's definitely worth getting to know them better.
The lectures are incredible; the assignments are substantial but not too much so; the tests are very reasonable. Overall, a fantastic course that does not require any changes.
This course is very broad. I wish we could have focused more on certain parts that were crucial for the development of robots today.

I think this course had a lot of strengths, especially the lectures and homeworks. I particularly enjoyed the coding homeworks. I thought the design homeworks were confusing and it was hard to get help on them.
Scaz is a super engaging lecturer! Some homework were a big step up in difficulty from lectures and exams covered a lot of small details. Material is generally very interesting!

Strength: the material is interesting, Scaz is great, and a lot of the class is talking about cool robots. Weakness: the early assignments concentrate on design more than programming, and that can be hard for computer science students. I also found they were graded on the harsher side.
Scaz lectures very well

The biggest strength of this course was the professor. Scaz did a great job making sure that each lecture was engaging and informative. I also appreciated how interdisciplinary the course was, in that we saw not only topics in computer science but also touched on topics in biology and psychology. The main way I feel like the course could be improved is I wish that we had gone into more depth into a few topics rather than a cursory overview of a bunch of different topics. I also wish we had more assignments that involved programming.

Strengths: Scaz is a great lecturer and robotics is a very interesting field.

Weaknesses: Psets were hard and required independent time to understand, because lectures did not dive deep enough into topics.

The great strength of this course was that the psets reflected, tested, reinforced what we learned in class. The weakness of this course is that it is a survey course and there were many topics we just weren't able to learn about in deapth

The lectures are fantastic. Honestly, the course had well thought out material, the expectations were reasonable, and the tests were fair. The weakest part of the class was the problem sets. Clarifications would come out late, or points would be deducted for things not specified in the assignment. Clearer communication for those would be much appreciated.
Scaz is an amazing lecturer who really keep you engaged with the material. The psets in the second half of the course are also very interesting-you get to implement a genetic algorithm.

The lectures for this course were engaging and interesting, and were very well organized - Scaz was able to fit a lot of information into the semester. This class felt more like a history than a computer science class. This isn't necessarily a weakness, but as a computer science major I wanted more coding. It was interesting working with the simulation program towards the end of the semester, and I think more problem sets could incorporate that software.
Psets don't contribute to learning and are really superficial

I think both the problem sets and lectures were strengths of this course. The problem sets were doable but also challenging. I feel that I learned about how to design architectures from the problem sets. The lectures were very well put together, informative and interesting.

At times I think the lectures could have been a little more detailed in the material they present. Also, the test could more closely match what was covered in class.

We learned about many different robotics systems and technologies, but sometimes it was confusing how each part fit together and related to each other. Also, with some of the more technical skills and details we learned, we didn't do many examples in class, so it was hard to implement them in the psets.

A lot of the lectures were very, very interesting, and the psets (especially the last two) were actually really fun. The first couple of psets were a little vague in what they asked for. I felt really supported by the teaching staff.

Strengths: Lots of fun information learned, Scaz is super knowledgeable and makes everything interesting
Weakness: the exams and p sets are all over the place. The homeworks have a sort of arbitrary grading scale and feedback isn't the most clear on it and the exams test a lot of seemingly random details that aren't always covered in the homework or extensively in class. It's kind of a mixed bag

The lectures are very interesting and Scaz showed us many cool videos about robots. The workload is also relatively light (3 lectures a week) and the problem sets are not hard. However, sometimes the problem sets leave you hanging as it covers content not exactly covered in class and so you will have to go for office hours to clarify many concepts.

Strengths- Scaz is a great lecturer! The lectures had fantastic material and it was really engaging. I did not want to miss this class. I also quite enjoyed the psets, even though some of them were really frustrating in the moment to work through, however figuring them out was a great feeling. 
Weaknesses- Office hours were relatively infrequent compared to other classes of similar sizes, more teaching staff could be used in the future. The psets could have been more balanced so that the latter did not take as long as the former took longer.

The lectures for this course were a genuine pleasure to sit through. The professor was engaging, the material was interesting, and the slides were easy to follow. You could really tell Scaz cared about what he was talking about. However, while the final exam was great, the midterm was rather difficult and some homework assignments were also hard. Overall, a really interesting class, but not necessarily an easy one.

The course was structured in a very organized way conducive to learning. Scaz always tried to tie new topics in with what we learned before. The psets were interesting and not super time-intensive. Scaz is also very very knowledgable about his field and very skilled at breaking down what he knows at a understandable level, even for non-cs majors. My favorite part of class was when he told stories about different robots. The only thing I think could be improved is that Scaz could add some time for questions. The earlier pset problems were also mostly subjective questions, and it seemed like the TAs took points off arbitrarily, so more coding / objective-oriented psets would be cool.
One of the most interesting courses at Yale for anyone with a slight interest in robotics. The professor is amazing. I only wish there were more computer science-related psets.
If you are a computer science student and looking for a not-too-time-consuming, yet interesting elective I would recommend.
If you're looking for something to fulfill your elective requirement with not a ton of work, I would recommend this class.
Yes! One of the better CS elective. Problem sets are interesting and challenging (at least the programming assignments are); and Scaz and the TAs are well-organized and helpful.
yes

The psets were engaging and educational, but the first few caused a ton of stress because the grading seemed so difficult to predict. The same goes for the tests - even though I understood all of the material, it seemed there were too many opportunities to get points off for misinterpreting the expectations. I was constantly stressed not because the material was hard, but because I wasn't sure how the TA would decide to grade...
Yes! This is a great CS elective.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student; even though CS201 and 202 are prereqs, I didn't take 202 and I was totally fine. I had to brush up on coding in C, but only 2 of the 5 problem sets required coding at all and it was totally doable to figure out. If you know C, you definitely don't need the prereqs. I thought this class was super interesting because it combined robotics and human psychology; we talked a lot about how humans interacted with robots and I thought that was very interesting. If you're interested in robot design, the history of robotics, and how humans interact with robots, totally take this course. The problem sets do use open ended design questions; I know other people didn't like that, but I loved it. It allows you to come up with really creative solutions, and as long as it works, then you're right. You aren't bound by stringent requirements for the problem sets, but I know other people didn't like the lack of structure. It depends on what you want out of the course.

I recommend this course to any one looking for a survey class in robotics. The main thing is that this class is honestly probably more of a social science class then it is any kind of normal computer science elective.

I would recommend the course as taught by Scaz. Go to every class (including Friday lectures) and studying for exams + the few problem sets will be easy. The course is not technically difficult and is a bit multi-disciplinary, which makes it a really nice elective to include among all the other EE/CS options. If you're looking for a class on how to program and operate robots, this is not for you. If you want interesting concepts to think about and ways to go about designing robots and how robots interact with the world, this will be appropriate.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. It's an interesting, useful, and exciting course.

The course deals with one of the most interesting problems of our age - attempting to imbue 'intelligence' in robots. Take it if you would like to get a broad overview of the field and learn how implementing even a seemingly trivial behavior can be extremely challenging. However, note that the programming component of the course is minimal, and if you've already taken courses in AI you may not learn much that is new.
Absolutely. Scaz is a fantastic lecturer, and the material speaks for itself.
Yes
Yes. It is definitely a fascinating class, and it touches on aspects of design that very few other CS electives offer.

This course is overall pretty good. Scaz is a great lecturer but you should definitely attend lecture. The design homeworks are very challenging and the coding homeworks fairly straightforward. The exams involve some trivia.
Yes if youre willing to put in work for exams and psets
I would recommend this course to another student; it was a fun CS elective and I was able to learn a lot about the field of robotics.
Yes. Amongst the field of CS electives, robotics was pretty chill and interesting. The exams were hard and based on memorization, though.

As far as cs electives go, this is a good one. Scaz is a good lecturer and definitely keeps the lectures engaging. The TAs are wonderful people and very helpful and the work load is challenging but not outrageous. I didn't think that the exams were always the best in terms of material tested.

This was essentially a history class. Most of the things we learn about are not used today. That said, as a class with a historical lens, it is great at what it does. (There are 3 coding problem sets, using the software package Webots and coded in C, but the lecture material focus is largely historical.)

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! This is a great course where you can sit back, listen and let Scaz change your perception of robot. It's a unique CS class that you don't want to miss out on!

I would recommend this course - it's an interesting class that fits nicely within a busy schedule. If you attend lecture and pay attention, you won't have any major challenges and you'll learn some interesting stuff along the way.

I would recommend this to anyone interested in learning more about the software behind robotics. I would recommend it to a friend because I found the lectures very interesting and the problem sets challenging but engaging. It does especially well assuming no knowledge of robotics.

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants a broad overview of the field of intelligent robotics. You learn about everything from low-level mechanisms to more abstract concepts and ideas in Intelligent Robotics. It doesn't go into much detail on any one particular topic, but it gives you an overarching understanding about the field and how the major ideas and technologies in the field have progressed over time. Scaz is a great lecturer, which is great because it's important to go to lecture in order to understand the slides. The psets are sometimes difficult because you don't go into so much detail about them in class, and also sometimes are only really doable if you wheedle some vital hints out of the TA, but there are only a couple of them.

Definitely take this course. Scaz is a great lecturer, and the psets are pretty fun, especially the last two. The topics are really interesting, especially for people who don't have any experience with robotics or AI/machine learning, and who want to learn.

Yes if you're interested in taking a class that is interesting and will teach you about how robots evolve and how the theory has changed. Don't take this class if you're looking for practical/classroom-to-lab knowledge because the theory isn't always directly applicable to anything. But it is fun and you will enjoy lectures.
Yes if you are interested in robotics, even if you are not a computer science/engineering major. However, a few of the problem sets requires some coding background. Overall very fun and chill class.
Definitely take this class! It's a great CS elective, Scaz is a great lecturer, you learn interesting material and the psets are time consuming but fun!

Yes, especially if Scaz is teaching it. It is so hard to find a CS class where the lectures are truly engaging, and this is one of the few. While the midterm might be difficult and you do need to go to every single class if you want to do well on any assessments, it is definitely worth it.
Yes!! This is a great 4th or 5th class and worth taking whether you're a CS major or not. The lectures are super interesting, and Scaz is probably the best lecturer I've had at Yale so far.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in robotics. It's a relatively low-workload computer science elective, but you probably won't learn a lot of heavy CS skills unless you were particularly interested in studying robotics. It's a niche class/field.

Overall, a really unpleasant experience. Homework is arbitrarily graded, test questions are arbitrarily chosen (8 questions, 10 points each). Lecture is pretty interesting sometimes, but the content just doesn't feel relevant most of the time. 2/5 psets were interesting/satisfying to do, the rest were just painful and annoying. Some questions the TA's have a hard time grading (like drawings of complicated diagrams, where they'll just take off points because "it's messy." Would not recommend as a CS elective credit - I had thought it was a gut, but it's the worst kind of class, where it takes an annoying amount of time and you don't learn anything.
